course.subject: MATH
course.name: Introduction to Optimization
course.description: This course introduces fundamental theory and techniques of optimization. Topics include linear programming, unconstrained optimization, and constrained optimization. Numerical implementations of optimization methods are also discussed.
course.prerequisites: (MATH 2011 OR MATH 2023) AND (MATH 2111 OR MATH 2121 OR MATH 2131)

reviews.author: UnconMarketeers
reviews.title: The course is partially saved
reviews.comment_content:
Prerequisites:

1. Multivariable calculus (Essential - Algorithms are derived using calculus)
2. Linear algebra (Essential - Tedious matrix computation is required for "running the algorithm" by hand)
3. Experiences on AI and machine learning (Nonessential - No coding is required, but the algorithms are applicable as AI algorithms)
4. Functional analysis (Nonessential - Familiarity on Hilbert space theory may be good for content related to proximal operator)

The course is divided as follows:

1. Preliminary (mathematical review)

-> Multivariable calculus
-> Some key topological properties (convexity plays a key role in optimization theory)

Comment: This part should not exist at all... Nothing to say.

2. Methods for differentiable functions

-> Gradient descent
-> Newton's method
-> Conjugate algorithm
-> Nesterov acceleration

Comment: For each of these algorithms, convergence analysis and choice of hyperparameters are discussed.

3. Methods for nondifferentiable convex functions

-> Subdifferenital (Extension of derivative in convex sense)
-> Proximal operator
-> FBS algorithm

4. Method of duality

-> Definition of dual problem
-> Weak and strong duality, slater condition and slater theorem
-> KKT condition and strong duality for convex problem
-> Linear programming (Duality method, simplex, path-following...)
-> First order optimization (projected gradient descent and Uzawa algorithm)
reviews.comment_teaching: Didn't go to the class. The main lecture discussed proofs and simple examples. More advanced examples are available in tutorial notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
30% homework, 20% quiz, 50% final.

Comment: It is a scam in some sense: The original plan is to have a project which requires coding instead of 2 quizzes.
reviews.comment_workload:
5 homework, either in some famous textbook like "Convex Optimization" or "An Introduction to Optimization" or elsewhere that I don't know. The questions are either propose an algorithm, or to run an algorithm by hand.

The quizzes are focused on the first three topics I mentioned in the "content" part. Some problems in quizzes reappear in the exam. I'm quite surprised that there are multiple choice questions in the exam and quizzes given that it is a 4000-level course...
